sections.title: A Prayer for God's Mercy on Israel
Prayer for the Vindication of God's People

verses.text: Have mercy upon us, O Lord God of all, and look upon us,
verses.comment: The chapter begins with an urgent prayer for God's mercy and attention, echoing petitions common in the Psalms.
verses.sectionHeader: A Prayer for God's Mercy on Israel

verses.text: and send your fear upon all the nations that do not know you,
verses.comment: The prayer seeks not only restoration for Israel but also the recognition of God's power by the nations, prefiguring God's plan for all peoples.

verses.text: Lift up your hand against foreign nations and let them see your might.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the uniqueness of God, a strong affirmation of monotheism vital to Old Testament revelation, ultimately fulfilled in the unity of faith Christ prays for (John 17:3).

verses.text: As you have used us to show your holiness to them, so use them to show your glory to us.
verses.comment: A yearning for new manifestations of God's power, recalling the miraculous works in Israel's history and looking forward to the ultimate sign in the resurrection of Jesus (Matt. 12:39-40).

verses.text: Then they will know, as we have known, that there is no God but you, O Lord.
verses.comment: The reference to God's 'right arm' alludes to divine intervention and salvation—themes fulfilled in Christ, who is seated at the right hand of the Father.

verses.text: Give new signs, and work other wonders;
verses.comment: This echoes imprecatory prayers and reminds us that God's justice is part of His love, culminating in the Last Judgment (Rev. 20:12).

verses.text: make your hand and right arm glorious.
verses.comment: This prayer for deliverance from enemies reflects both the physical and spiritual struggles of God's people. Spiritually fulfilled through Christ's defeat of sin and death (1 Cor. 15:54-57).

verses.text: Rouse your anger and pour out your wrath;
verses.comment: Restored missing invocation to divine judgment as found in Greek manuscripts.

verses.text: destroy the adversary and wipe out the enemy.
verses.comment: Corrected to contain only the adversary and enemy destruction element.

verses.text: Hasten the day, and remember the appointed time, and let people recount your mighty deeds.
verses.comment: Reinstated original prayer for prompt judgment and remembrance of God's deeds.

verses.text: Let survivors be consumed in the fiery wrath, and may those who harm your people meet destruction.
verses.comment: Restored full verse content calling for retribution upon Israel's oppressors.

verses.text: Crush the heads of hostile rulers who say, “There is no one but ourselves.”
verses.comment: Ensured correspondence to the plea for the downfall of arrogant rulers.

verses.text: Gather all the tribes of Jacob,
verses.comment: Jerusalem, the 'city of God's rest,' is central in Salvation History—pointing forward to the heavenly Jerusalem (Heb. 12:22; Rev. 21:2), and the place God dwells among His people.

verses.text: Have mercy, O Lord, upon the people called by your name, upon Israel, whom you have named your firstborn.
verses.comment: This verse invokes God's covenant mercy toward Israel, echoing Exodus 4:22 where Israel is called God's 'firstborn,' highlighting their unique status among nations and the enduring theme of divine election and compassion.

verses.text: Give testimony to those whom you created from the beginning, and raise up the prophetic words spoken in your name.
verses.comment: A plea for God to confirm and fulfill His promises through the message of the prophets, fully realized in Christ, the ultimate Prophet.

verses.text: and give them their inheritance, as at the beginning.
verses.comment: The faithfulness of the prophets is vindicated when God fulfills their words. The faithful are assured of reward, a foreshadowing of the beatific vision promised to God's people.
verses.sectionHeader: Prayer for the Vindication of God's People

verses.text: Hear, O Lord, the prayer of your servants, according to the blessing of Aaron over your people, and all who dwell on earth will acknowledge that you are the Lord, the God of the ages.
verses.comment: The Aaronic blessing is a sign of God's enduring favor—a powerful connection to the sacramental life that extends the blessing to all nations in Christ (cf. Acts 3:25-26).

verses.text: The stomach takes different kinds of food, and the heart discerns different thoughts.
verses.comment: Transition from prayer to wisdom sayings: physical appetite is compared with spiritual discernment—foreshadowing the importance of rightly formed conscience.

verses.text: As the palate tastes the game of the hunt, so a wise mind discerns lying words.
verses.comment: Acute discernment is a mark of wisdom—fulfilled especially in Christ, who is Truth incarnate (John 14:6).

verses.text: A perverse heart will cause grief, but an experienced person will repay it with understanding.
verses.comment: Contrasting the effect of a depraved heart and the wisdom of the mature—pointing to the need for the renewal of mind in Christ (Rom. 12:2).

verses.text: A woman will accept any man as a husband, but one woman is more sensible than another.
verses.comment: Wisdom in marriage is valued—recalling the biblical ideal of a virtuous spouse (Prov. 31), reflecting deeper truths about God's covenant love.

verses.text: A woman's beauty gladdens the face, and surpasses every desire of man.
verses.comment: Physical beauty is acknowledged as a good, yet underlines the deeper goodness of God's creation and hints at the desire for divine beauty, fulfilled in the vision of God.

verses.text: The stomach will take any food, yet one food is better than another.
verses.comment: The spiritual virtues of kindness and humility are of greater value than physical beauty. This echoes the New Testament emphasis on interior holiness (1 Pet. 3:3-4).

verses.text: As the palate tastes the kinds of game, so an intelligent mind detects false words.
verses.comment: Marriage is understood as a partnership ordained by God, reflecting the deeper mystery of Christ and His Church (Eph. 5:32)—the mutual help and sanctification the union brings.

verses.text: A perverse mind will cause grief, but a person with experience will pay him back.
verses.comment: Stresses the protective value of marriage, portraying the domestic union as ordered by providence and necessary for human fulfillment.

verses.text: A woman will accept any man as a husband, but one girl is preferable to another.
verses.comment: Lack of rootedness is compared to instability and mistrust. Spiritual stability is found in faithfulness and in one's proper vocation.

verses.text: A woman’s beauty lights up a man’s face, and there is nothing he desires more.
verses.comment: Restates the image of wandering, suggesting the natural human desire for belonging and stability, ultimately fulfilled in our heavenly home (Heb. 13:14).

verses.text: If kindness and humility mark her speech, her husband is more fortunate than other men.
verses.comment: Echoes Proverbs 31—wisdom as embodied in a spouse is of inestimable value, both for the home and spiritual life.

verses.text: He who acquires a wife gets his best possession, a helper fit for him and a pillar of support.
verses.comment: Final verse compares home life and natural order, reflecting the belief that virtue and domestic harmony image God's own beauty and order.

verses.text: Where there is no fence, the property will be plundered; and where there is no wife, a man will become a fugitive and a wanderer.
verses.comment: The lampstand (menorah) is a symbol of God's presence in the sanctuary, linking domestic and sacred imagery. It also foreshadows Christ as the Light of the world (John 8:12).

verses.text: For who will trust a nimble robber that skips from city to city? So who will trust a man that has no nest, but lodges wherever night overtakes him?
verses.comment: Concludes with an image from temple architecture, praising both bodily and spiritual virtues within the home.
